title: Cropping land prices outperform all other types of farmland
text:
Amid the crippling drought that is devastating many farming families, the value of prime farmland used to grow crops has been increasing at close to double-digit annual rates over the past five years, outperforming all other types of farmland.

A new Rabobank report shows prices for dryland cropping land

have risen by a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 9.1 per cent over the past five years at a national level, compared with 5.1 per cent for dairy land values and just 2 per cent for pastoral grazing land.

Cropping land prices have surged in parts of NSW and Victoria. Getty

This growth has been driven by strong demand for land in areas with favourable growing seasons as farmers look to expand and, more recently, by a lack of properties on the market, particularly in drought-affected regions with overall rural property listings estimated to be down by more than 50 per cent on 2014 in many parts of the country.

“Demand for cropping land has been particularly intense over this period, which has accelerated the increase in cropping land prices, relative to other commodity sectors," said Rabobank agricultural analyst and author of its Overshot and Undershort Report, Wes Lefroy.
description: They have risen by a compound annual growth rate of 9.1 per cent over the past five years, leaving dairy and grazing land growth far behind, a Rabobank report shows.
